def: not harmful
ex: Tommy's Snake Juice might have seemed innocuous at first, yet it destroyed the crew and gave them the worst hangovers the day after.

def: to chose not to take part in or consume
ex: Jamm abstained from the vote on the sale of the land after both his competitors helped him get out of Tammy 2's grasp.

def: showing modest resrve, lacking self-confidence (adj)
ex: Leslie vowed to fix Shawna's diffident nature if she picked her to replace Ann as a friend. Leslie was annoyed with how Shawna let men use her.

def: not inclined towards physical exertion or effort, slow and relaxed
ex: Pam and Jim's languid fun run ended up being a win for everyone as they had bought a lamp that they handed to Michael as an award.

def: harsh in tone
ex: Angela was acerbic towards Meredith, harshly judging and talking about her sex life.

def: to make something bad better
ex: Pam tried to ameliorate Michael's existential pain at the bird funeral by make a speech that really resonated with Michael's anxieties. He seemed better after that.

def: (adj) characterized by extreme care / principled or having high morals
ex: Hermonie was scrupulous when it came to making poly juice potion, yet her great care failed her when it came to pi of a cat hair. Harry's scrupulous behavior towards enemies always surprises his friend, like when he saved Malfoy from the burning room of rquim.

def: (n) an excessive supply, (v) to supply with an excess
ex: The glut in supply of paper vs the decrease in demand caused a drop in the price of paper, which is why DunderMifflin had to close its doors. Too much supply always lowers the price.

def: dishonorable
ex: Dwight's attempt to take over as branch manager was the most ignoble act he ever committed. He infact admitted to Michael that it was the most dishonorable thing he ever did.

def: demanding strict attention to rules and details
ex: McGonogal was stringent about letting students go to Hogsmead without permission, not letting Harry go even if she'd signed it.

def: narrow in scope
ex: The office is parochial in setting, where most of the scenes are based in the building in Scranton, whereas Parks and Rec travels all around the US for Leslie's job.

def: difficult to understand, incomprehensible
ex: Leslie found most of the sci fi Ben enjoyed to be abstruse. She could not wrap her head around Game of Thrones or Star Wards.

def: firm and dependable in loyalty
ex: Leslie is a very staunch supporter of more government building of parks, whereas Ron is firmly against that.

def: to spread negative information about
ex: Sweetums and Councilman Jamm did their best to vilify Leslie as a terrible government bureuacrat to get her to lose the recall election.

def: to speak evasively
ex: While Jim went straight to the point about the raises, Michael prevaricated about what his plan is and never gave an actual concrete plan.

def: wasting resources recklessly (adj) or those who do that (n)
ex: Eagletonians are terrible profligates. They have a department of Infinity Pools that's so profligate, Leslie closed it and put the department on hold.

def: to come from, be connected to, or to deduce by reason
ex: April's hate for Ann was derived from their competition over Andy as Ann had dated Andy for two years before April.

def: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy
ex: Andy's haughty attitude about studying at Cornell was quickly crushed by how incompetent he is as a salesman.

def: traveling from place to place to work
ex: Packer's itinerant job as a traveling salesman makes him an aannoying recurrent character that shows up to miss everything up and then leave it for the office to handle..

def: properity in manners and conduct
ex: Angela's decorum in almost everything does not fit the sex-crazed side of her that we know. Outside of bed, she seems to care about doing everything just as politely as any queen would.

def: charming in a childlike or naive way
ex: Erin's winsome nature that wanted to watch cartoon movies did not match Gabe's nature that wanted to watch creepy movies. She was too childlike for Gabe to get.

def: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously
ex: Michael's volubility on stage is a strong characteristic of his speeches. He always has much to say and never seem to run out of words until someone stops him.

def: completely obvious
ex: Michael's balant ignorance was often tolerated or ignored the office, except when it was too right in their faces, like in a meeting, to be ignored.

def: to reveal unintentionally
ex: When asked by Ron, Jerry quickly betrayed Leslie's plans to find a historical connection to the land.

def: an absurd presentation of something, a mockery
ex: The dysfunctional nature of the council Leslie was on was a travesty of how city councils truely work. Yet, there's probably some truth to it nevertheless, which made it even more humorous.

def: extremely hungry, devouring food in great quantities
ex: Ron's ravenous apetite often annoyed Hermonie espicially when she was nervous about something, like when Harry was missing.

def: immitative of another work
ex: Parks and Rec might have felt derivative from the Office at first, but then it quickly took on a life of its own that made great.

def: the trait of seeming not to care
ex: The town's indifference to obesity and its health crisis drove Leslie mad, espicially as she tried to pass legislation to preclude unhealthy offerings in schools, but no one in the town seemed to care about their health.

def: cannot be changed
ex: Ron's position on government was immutable from the start, it could not be changed no matter how hard Leslie worked to show him the importance of government in people's lives.

def: stubbornly unyielding
ex: Leslie was very tenacious about building the park on that pit, and she got it done despite all the challenges.

def: lacking physical movement skills, espicially with the hands
ex: Kevin dropping the chili is typical of his bumbling hands. He's always dropping things, and lacks any physical momevement coordination.

def: easily irritated or annoyed
ex: Andy is always petulant when talking to Gabe, because he asked Erin out and they are dating. He would be all cheery and then Gabe would start talking and he gets irritated.

def: (adj) sharply contrasted in character or purpose
ex: Harry's character is deeply antithetical to Malfoy's. Where Malfoy was self-important and dependent, Harry was independent and humble.

def: (v) to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion or doubt with supporitng arguments or proof
ex: Leslie felt vindicated from any public mistreatment after she got the job as the head of National Parks.

def: plausable but false
ex: Tommy made a spurious claim that people call him the Indian Robert Dinero. It's plauable but definitely not true.

def: conpicuously and offensively loud, given to vehement outcry
ex: Oscar quickly regretted his vociferous comments to Michael, even though he was really hurt by the gay witch hunt which caused his outburst of anger.

def: easily persuaded
ex: Ann is pretty amenable to Leslie's force of will and over-the-top complements, so Leslie can usually get her to do anything, like leaving nursing to take up a government job.

def: shapeless
ex: What started out as an amorphous idea for a concert quickly took shape into a very detailed plan for a concert with some of the best bands in Indiana.

def: charge falsely or with malicious intent, attack the good name and reputation of someone
ex: Jamm and the Family Foundation denigrated Leslie for not showing up to the Pancake competition, but Ben and Leslie did notlet get their false charges get to them

def: favorable, not sinister
ex: The auspicious conditions at the Park encouraged Ron to take the job as head of the Park's rangers.

def: give extra weight to (a communication)
ex: The Red Cross coming to Pawnee underscored how terrile the health crisis has become in the town. It emphasized how much action was needed to prevent such diseases.

def: describing a statement that is not believeable
ex: Tommy's dreams for his business empire were implausible, as no one around him believed he could make it. Yet he did.

def: in abundant supply
ex: Despite what Dwight told the cops, they failed to find copious amounts of drugs in Toby's desk. Instead of the large amounts of drugs, all they found was salad in a bag.

def: fixed firmly or securely
ex: Dressing up for Halloween was very entrenched in the culture of the Scranton office, that when Pam worked at the HQ in NY, she was the only one dressed up.

def: deny or contradict; speak against or oppose
ex: No one dared to gainsay Michael after he screamed at them to get in the office for Holy's meeting

def: cancel officially
ex: Ben rescinded the offer to run for governor of Indiana ito let Leslie run.

def: disinclined to talk, not revealing one's thoughts
ex: Angela was very reticent about the fact that she did not think she did not like Andy or want to marry him.

def: a person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field
ex: Michael was a heretic on management. He always treated the office as a family, whereas every other manager treated their offices as workspace and everyone under them as employees.

def: cause to be more favorably inclined
ex: Voldemort's anger on Snape's lateness was placated by Snape's seemingly unquestionable loyality.

def: using very few words
ex: Ron's laconic nature was not wholy loved around the office, espicially when people needed long speeches to inspire them. Leslie covered that role pretty well, she had enough words for both them.

def: prone to unexpected and unpredicatable changes in mood
ex: Michael can pretty mercurial in some episodes. He either starts out really upset trying to bring everyone around him down and ends up as happy or satisfied. Or he starts out really happy and then something arises and he crumbles to sadness, and sometimes anger.

def: free of deceit
ex: Erin is the most guileless character on the Office, which made her endearing that she did not try to trick Andy in any way, yet hard to digest that she could not handle herself as an adult.

def: constituing a seperate entity or part
ex: The warehouse run by Darryl wbecame a discretee part, seperate from the Office, after the merger.

def: assign great social importance to
ex: Leslie often lionized random figures in government that eventually became her colleagues and lost the importance she had before assigned to them.

def: fanatical patriotism
ex: None of the shows I watch have any hit of jingoism. In fact, if itpatriotism comes up, it's usally in a sarcastic orsatirical way.

def: based on a random, groundless decision
ex: Michael's decision to give back the surplus seemed arbitrary until Oscar explained Michael would be getting a bonus.

def: highly opinionated, not accepting that your belief may be correct
ex: Angela's dogmatic idea of Christmas stopped her from enjoying the Morrocon Christmas, because it did not fit with what Christmas should be.

def: to make unclear (v), known only be a few (adj)
ex: Leslie is probably one of the few people who know the obscure fact that one President came from Pawnee, but quickly died and was replaced by his VP.

def: keep from happening, make it impossible
ex: Jamm did his best to preclude any effort of Leslie's to fix things to pass, yet she always found a way to make things work.

def: truthful
ex: Meridith was too veracious in the office meeting on ethics, betraying the secret that she sleeps with the supliers to get a discount.

def: the trait of avoiding excesses
ex: Kevin, not known for his temperance, had a whole jar of candy right on his disk that he always ate from.

def: guided by practical experience rather than theory
ex: After some time in the council, Leslie developed a pragmatic approach to getting what she wanted,. Experience had taught her that getting to know the councilmen on a personal level and compromises are better approach than philosophical appeals.

def: reject as untrue or unfounded
ex: Dwight could not repudiate all the false statements Jim was making about Battlestar Gallectica. Dwight would ususally not correcting any untrue facts about his favorite show.

def: tending to betray
ex: Dwight's treacherous meeting with Jan to take over Michael's position as manager was quickly forgiven by Michael , though not until he humiliated him enough.

def: lacking foresight or imagination
ex: Michael's myopic vision on the future paper was countered by his own temp, Ryan, who had the foresight to see that tech was eating paper.

def: moderated in effect
ex: Everyone was so used to Michael's antics that their response has become tempered and it took a lot more effort from Michael to get them riled up.

def: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
ex: The opulence of Sweetums was demonstrated by a charity arm that they used to show off how much money they can donate, which Ben did not mind as long as it went to the right causes.

def: respect deeply
ex: Leslie venerated Michelle Obama as a champion of women rights, though most women rights activists would agree she's not so special.

def: take the place of or move into the position of
ex: None of the managers brought in could really supplant Michael's role as manager. They had big shoes to fill.

def: to reprimand harshly
ex: Michael could not bring himself to castigate Kelly for lying about Jim and Dwight in her reports. She got away without much scolding.

def: repeated too often, overfamiliar through overuse
ex: Michael overused "thats what she said." The banal expression became a fixture of Michael's character.

def: availabel when required or as promised / at ease in talking to others
ex: Michael was not forthcoming about his life with Toby until Toby got him to play games with him to get him to talk.

def: expecting unquestioning obedience, characteristic of an absolute ruler
ex: The visitors from Pawnee's sister city were surprised by the lack of dictatorial power in the Parks Department. They were used to the absolute power they had back in their country.

def: adjective: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
ex: Harry was very reverent of Dumbledore, even Dumbledore's own brother  doubted him.

def: attentive in an ingratiating or servile manner, attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
ex: The Senator confused Leslie's venerating attitude towards him for obsequiousness and was annoyed by that. He was not a fan of sycophants who would get him water just to win favor with him

def: intellectually productive
ex: Tommy became a prolific writer after the failure of his empire, producing Failure and Failure2 in the span of a year, which is really productive.

def: not clearly understood or expressed
ex: Everyone found Andy's sexuality opaque. It was not clear whether he was gay or straight.

def: marked by or showing hopelessness
ex: Tommy seemed pretty forlorn about the fall of his empire, he could not image doing anything else. Yet, he found a way to bounce back as an author and all hope was restored.

def: marked by extreme intesity of emotions or convictions
ex: Michael was vehemently excited by Pam and Jim's engagement. He hugged Jim to the goround.

def: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy
ex: The private high-class club in the Office enjoy a delicacy of gossamer chocolate that were very delicate and light, brought over from France by Oscar.

def: very prominent, standing above others in quality or position
ex: By the end of the show, either Ben or Leslie held the eminent position as POTUS. We don't know who, though I like to think it was Leslie.

def: make worse
ex: Dwight exacerbated the situation by destroying the Red Cross's doll after the fire scare he created.

def: marked different from an accepted norm
ex: Dwight's diffidence after Angela dumped him was aberrant to his usual self-assured character.

def: being essentially equal to
ex: Jan's relationship with Michael is tantamount to Michael tying himself to a car thhat drives him off a cliff.

def: a large number
ex: Hogwarts students got to chose from a myriad of classes including potions, defense against the dark arts, history of magic, and many other less interesting classes.

def: a mixture of multiple things
ex: Jerry's family is a weird amalgam of ugly and beautiful.

def: to be in proportion or corresponding in degree or amount
ex: Dwight's response to the flashing incident was not commensurate with what the incident required. It was over the top and could not produce any results.

def: marked by a lack of interest
ex: Most of the office was apathetic towards the death of Michael's boss, whereas Michael was really upset.

def: hostile (conditions or environments)
ex: Harry, Ron, and Hermonie found most places inimical towards them after Voldemort came to power. They did not feel safe anywhere and could not trust many wizards.

def: to put side by side for contrast
ex: At first, it might seem easy to juxtapose the Office and Parks and Rec. You have the fun crazy passionate boss, the terrible intern, the funny sidekick, tall and handsome white man... Yet Parks and Rec is really its own monster even if it starts out really derivative. They become hard to compare very quickly.

def: distinctive and showy elegence
ex: Tommy was able to turn his panache into profit with Rent-a-swag. He had enough nelegant showy clothes that kids really wanted.

def: (n) group of people representing a larger group / (adj) dependent on (+ upon)
ex: The contingent representing the Scranton branch was led by Michael who put together a party wwhose success was contingent upon people actually coming to it.

def: a deviation from what is normal
ex: Family Rights Group in Pawnee made a fuss about the marriage of two penguins being an aberration against nature.

def: a trite or obvious remark
ex: The hooker's platitude on honesty worked better for Michael than the wise thoughtful advice from Benjamen Franklin.

def: to clarify, make easier to understand
ex: Prison Mike tried to elucidate what life in prison is like. He only confused everyone when he said "dementors"

def: overfamiliar through overuse
ex: Trite itself has become trite because it comes up in so many definitions and examples.

def: gain favor with somebody by deliberate efforts
ex: Andy's efforts to ingratiate himself to Michael backfired and ended up being pushed away by Michael as a suckup.

def: susceptible to bribes or corruption
ex: Leslie did not think she had an issue with venality. Yet after she chose to use the gift basket to impress her friends, she was extra careful about issues of corruption and bribery

def: to limit (a statement), make less severe
ex: All attempts to qualify Leslie's statements to suite all the different groups failed because they all wanted different and contradicting things.

def: fulll of joy / high-spirited merriment
ex: The Death Eaters were jovial at the death of Harry Potter, laughing in merriment at the end of their lord's enemy.

def: to reproach, to scold
ex: Jan upbraided Michael for his sex-charged humor, yet the scolding did not seem to matter to Michael more than being funny to be accepted by others.

def: being in the early stages of development, being or invovling basic facts or principles
ex: Sherlock has a knack for uncovering seemingly complex mysteries as rather rudimentaryy trickstery.

def: to express criticism towards
ex: Snape reproached Harry for coming to the castle late, almost to the point of insulting him and Serius which really annoyed Harry.

def: to weaken
ex: Dwight did his best to undermine Jim's role as co-manager, even inviting everyone in the office to revolt against him.

def: happy because of success
ex: Everyone was really jubilant for Leslie when Ben announced she's running for congress. They cheered and hugged her.

def: excluded from a community or group
ex: Hermonie was at first ostracized from other students from being too smart and knowledgable, but then she was quickly embraced by Ron and Harry after their fight with the troll.

def: mysterious or vague, usually unintentionally
ex: Jim and Pam's cryptic comments about her father were misunderstood by Andy as discussing the film.

def: be undecided about something, waver between conflicting positions
ex: Michael vacillated between the chairs and the printer and could not decide between the two positions on which to buy with the surplus. He kept wavering until everyone agreed.

def: lacking significance through having been overused
ex: 'That's what she said' might seem hackneyed to everyone else, but to Michael, it was still important and not overused. If anything, it was not used enough for Michael.

def: to chuckle merrily, often in a breathy, muffled way
ex: Michael chortled like a kid after saying 'that's what she said' after Jan forbade him to and Jim pushed him. That laughter was infectuous around the office.

def: of a belief that is based on faulty reasoning
ex: Michael tried to  disprove any fallacious notion that there's anything wrong with being gay by kissing Oscar, which must have been really hard for him to do

def: to make widely known
ex: The prophet disseminated the idea that Harry is the Chosen One. It's so that everyone thought Harry was the one to stop Voldemort.

def: not normal
ex: Dissing Pawnee in her speech was very anomalous to Leslie's character who always loved and praised it as the greatest city on earth.

def: reach the highest or most decisive point
ex: The Office christmas party culminated in Phyllis outing Angela screwing Dwight and Andy humiliating himself.

def: done with very great haste and without due deliberation
ex: Michael's precipitous hiring of their main competitor's salesman was done without consulting anyone in his office or management. He amde the decision in the heat of the moment.

def: timid by nature, revealing nervousness or fear
ex: Originally timorous as a kid, Neville developed into a confident and charming man. Any nervousness or fear would not be found on his face as he killed Nigini.

def: instructive (excessively)
ex: Leslie's didactic form of management taught her employees how to take control of their own careers and succeed at them. She used every opportunity as a chance to teach one of them something.

def: to misrepresent
ex: Chris Tager belied any negative comments as positive messages, which made his message ambiguous.

def: wastefully extravagant
ex: The department of infinity pools is Eaglton's most prodigal expense. It was quickly cut by Ben for being to extravagent and wasteful.

def: requiring and demanding accuracy
ex: Leslie was always very exacting of her employees to the point of micro-management. SExcept Jerry, who she never demanded do an accurate job because she did not trust him to ever do so.

def: to be naive and ignorant
ex: Erin's character is pretty ingenuous when it comes to relationships. It's especially bad since Andy does not know what he's doing either.

def: to completely destroy
ex: Dwight had a plan to eradicate the office of any incompetent people from the office, which included removing Kevin and neither of them liked that.

def: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends to have knowledge
ex: Kevin was a dilettante in making chili. He would often make it for fun and take some to work, and even compete in chili competitions but he does not take it very seriously

def: rude and ignorant
ex: The old councilman's insolent comments about women and superiority of white men did not sit well with Leslie but she could  not reply to his rude and arrogant comments.

def: a state of guilt/responsibility for bad action
ex: Ben accepted culpability for Ice Town and the amendment Gryzzle sneaked into the agreement.

def: characteristic of one eager to fight
ex: Everyone in the public hearing on building the park was belligerent towards Leslie , that she felt very angry and ended the meeting early.

def: incosistent, lacking in harmony or compatability or appropriateness
ex: Michael's image of the office as a family was probably incongruous with how others thought about it, espicially at the start when they could not wait to leave the office.

def: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
ex: Michael is the iconoclast of what a manager is. He often breaks into song and games, rather than what most managers do acting like policeman over their teams.

def: (v) to give authority to, (n) a legal penalty for a forbidden action
ex: Andy sanctioned Dwight's doomday device without knowing he was giving Dwight the authority to end the branch.

def: recurring in scattered and irregular o runpredictable instances
ex: The disappearances were at first sporadic then quickly became consistent, occuring almost daily, which clearly signalled the return of the Dark Lord.

def: restrict or confine
ex: Umbridge circumscribed the students learning to only books and reading, and never to actually use any magic

def: one who professes great sensetivity ot the beauty of art and nature
ex: Ron's an aesthete who appreciates nature more than anything else. The job Leslie got him as Park Ranger truely suited his nature as he got to spend most of the time outside.

def: to cleverly find a way out of obligations
ex: Michael circumvents doing any real work by pretending to be sick. Michael has  some kind of ache somewhere 40 times a year and Dwight takes it fairly seriously every time.

def: in opposition to an established system or institution
ex: Ron's subsersive efforts against the government failed to produce any measurable results, not even slow the Parks department because Leslie ran it so well.

def: worthy of high praise
ex: Pam's way of becoming an office administrator was very laudable for its ingenuity. In fact, I am sure Jim praised her alot for her quick thinking.

def: unbiased, neutral
ex: Jamm took a disinterested position after Leslie and Ron both helped him escape Tammy's clutch.

def: showing respect
ex: Dwight is very deferential to Michael, to the point of worship.

def: someone whohas been admitted to membership ina scholarly field
ex: Ryan took Michael to his classroom as a pundit on paper and business, yet no one in the room considered him an expert on business after his speech.

def: praise or glorify
ex: Tom exalted everything popish and rap culture, yet failed to praise or care for anything in his own Indian culture.

def: (adj) having only one meaning or interpretation, admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding
ex: Ron made his stance on government unequivocally clear to Leslie, tyet she could  not but misunderstand his very clear statements.

def: acknowledge defeat / admit  / give over or relinquish control
ex: Michael would never concede that he was wrong. He would circumvent any responsibility like when he hit Meredith with his car and then claimed he saved her from raibies.

def: characteristic of rural life; awakwardly simple and provicinal
ex: Dwight's farm had a rustic charm that made Jim and Pam really enjoy their first trip away together.

def: occuring by happy chance, having no obvious cause
ex: It was really fortuitous that Pam met Jim, else she would have married that guy which would be unlucky.

def: to excite or inspire
ex: Leslie galvanized her department to put on a great Harvest Festival that saved the city of Pawnee from bankruptcy.

def: discontented as toward authority
ex: After knowing that Michael could get a bonus instead of the surplus, everyone became disaffected  and united on buying the chairs.

def: to make less angry, to placate (v)
ex: Ann and Ben always mollify Leslie with pancakes when giving her news she might not like

def: making of a false statement meant to injure a person's reputation
ex: The recall election against Leslie Knope was full of calumny against her. Jamm insisted she wanted to destroy their American way of living and other such lies.

def: grow or flourish
ex: Pawnee burgeoned as a city from a town after the National Parks Service moved in

def: dominance over a certain area
ex: The Shrutes have had hegemony over their lands for decades, so when the government came to take a chunk of their land,  they were pissed.

def: inactivity resulting from lethargy and lack of vigor or energy
ex: Playing crossward and napping in his chair are charateristic of Stanley's torpor.

def: add details or explanation, clarify the meaning, state in depth
ex: Prison Mike expounded on his experience of prison, delineating how dementors keep prisoners in check.

def: improperly forward or bold
ex: Leslie's impudent move to get Gryzzle to move into the old part of town and give away the park paid off handsomely and she got what she wanted. It might have seemed improper to some people, but it was bold.

def: without scruples or principles
ex: Newport's campaign manager was unscrupulous in running the campaign, using every tactic to destroy Leslie without any concern for principles that Leslie cared for.

def: working in subtle/gradual destructive/sinister way
ex: Andy's insidious comments about Dwight were met with rejection from Michael. Michael loved Dwight no matter who hard Andy worked to change that.

def: characterized by good taste in manners and conduct
ex: Michael and Dwight break every decorous rule at thee dinner party hosted by Wallace.

def: willing to be bold or to take risks
ex: Michael is pretty audacious when it comes to public speaking. If there's a mic there, he's bold enough to get up and take it - I Braveheart

def: habitually reserved and uncommunicative
ex: Oscar is often taciturn about his sex life, but the people around the office always find a way to break his reservation and get him to talk about it.

def: risisng agian to new life and vigor
ex: The resurgent Dark Forces could not be stopped by the wizarding community even as they warned early on of the return of the Dark Lord.

def: to warn strongly, even to the point of reprimanding
ex: The government admonished its employese against taking any strong stance. Their warnings often failed to have any effect on the very polticized environments of government offices.

def: extremely frugal
ex: April and Andy were a parsimonious couple at the start, eating out of frisbees

def: noble and generous in spirit, espicially towards a rival or someone less in power
ex: Leslie's attempt at getting the Newports to be magnanimous by giving her the land for free did not work because Grizzle paid more than 125 million dollars for the land.

def: marked by repeated turns and bend, not straightforward
ex: Michael built a tortuous track for hamseters to run in around his office. The track went around in circles and up, down and around the office.

def: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
ex: The harvest festival was prodigious in scale, bringing in thousands of people from around Indiana and saving the government, and aimpressing everyone in Pawnee with the Parks Department.

def: still in existence (in reference to documents)
ex: After 30 years, Leslie and Ben were suprised to find her River Cleanup document was still extant in Public Work circles as an example of great work.

def: restless
ex: The office was pretty restive after drinking too much coffee from the espresso machine. They could hardly sit down quietly for a few minutes.

def: a long pompous speed or tirade (n), or to deliver such one (v)
ex: Leslie's harangue about Pawnee's lack of appreciation for her work was met with disapproval from the people of Pawnee and contributed to her loosing the election.

def: lacking solish polish
ex: Jim tried to improve on Dwight's gauche behavior to help him get his revenge on the mall.

def: unsure how to react or respond
ex: Harry was nonplussed about how to convince Ron and Hermonie that Malfoy is a deatheater.

def: shockingly bad
ex: Dwight's most egregious mistake was never telling anyone but his relationship to Angela.

def: releating to pleasent aspects of the country
ex: The bucolic scenes on the trip Leslie sent Ron in Scotland really got him almost feeling sentimental and very deeply enjoyed the experience.

def: based on pretense, deceptively pleasing; plausable but false
ex: Gilderoy Lockhart's specious stories about his adventures did not hold true when faced with real danger.

def: readily retracting to suggestions and influences, easily managed (controlled taught or molded)
ex: Andy's diffident character made him more tractable than the other characters in the show like Darryl who was self assured enough that he was not easily influenced by others.

def: to reprimand harshly and punish
ex: Dwight got chastised for sending Phyllis walking on her own to lose weight for the office. It did not seem that the reprimand was enough.

def: typical, found in the ordinary course of events
ex: Pretending to be Dwight is the quotidian prank that's typical of Jim's relationship to Dwight.

def: complicated / difficult to comprehend
ex: Fixing the printer seemed like an involved task at first, but Pam found herself up to the task.

def: habitual
ex: Stanely was an inveterate napper. He would often nap in the middle of work or in meetings.

def: not spending much money (spending wisely)
ex: Any sense frugality was thrown out of the door on 'treat yo self' day, even by Ben who bought a Batman custom.

def: (adj) characterized by or characteristic of exceptionally early development or maturity (especially in mental aptitude)
ex: Even as a kid, Leslie was a precocious govenment worker. She even wrote down in her diary that she'd become a governor of Indiana.

def: being of questionable authenticity
ex: Gabe found Pam's position as Office Administrator apocryphal because he could not find proof ofthat the position ever existed. He wondered if she was lying.

def: compulsory force or threat
ex: Cho confessed their meeting location under duress. Umbridge used the truth serum on her and even threatned the Cruciatux curse.

def: concerned with the apprecaitoin of beauty (adj), set of principles underlying an artistic movement or a particular artist
ex: Pam's aesthetic sense may seem foreign and unoriginal to some, as an audience and fans, her art and sense of beauty becomes rather personal

def: practicing self-denial
ex: The Office's ascetic month trying to losing weight ended up being ineffective against the power of cake.

def: incapable of making less angry or hostile
ex: Dwight was implacable after Angela chose Andy, no matter how hard Jim or Phyllis tried to cheer him up.

def: a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes / an abstract part of something
ex: Leslie did her best to represent her constituents and do what's best for them, , yet that's not always aligned with what they thought was best for them.

def: make two things compatible with each other
ex: It tdid not take much to reconcile Angela and Dwight after their breakup. They just cannot keep their hands off each other even though each vowed to stay away.

def: splendid and expensive looking
ex: The sumptuous-looking handle Malfoy had on his wand was immediately thrown by Voldemort when he took his wand.

def: not easily understood, unfathomable
ex: Michael made his speech inscrutable to Darryl, so much that Darryl could not hear him or understand what he's saying, a technique he learned from wikipedia to assert dominance and stop Darryl from asking ofor a raise.

def: to plan or scheme
ex: April contrived of a plan to both fix animal control and not have to run it,. The plan was so good that the council immediately approved it.

def: (v) be a sign or indication of, have meaning
ex: Michael standing up on a podium and make a speech usually denotes that something really cringy is about to happen.

def: to cause confusion / mistake on thing for another
ex: Michael confounded 'oh how the tables turn' with 'oh how turntables'.

def: the power to forsee the future
ex: Jim did not have enough prescience to remember to tell the guards not to lock the building when they stayed late to do reports.

def: unwilling to change one's beliefs or course of action
ex: Pam was intransigent that she wanted new chairs. She maintained her position even when Jim sided with getinng a new printer and would not change her mind.

def: full of trivial conversation
ex: Kelly was garrulous on celebrities. Even when Jim asked her about herself, she answered by talking about Tom Cruise's new baby.

def: the trait of being rude and impertinent / feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill-will
ex: Michael had the gall to claim he saved Meridith after hitting her with his car. The gall between Ron and Leslie was quickly desipated after a night of reconcilation.

def: to weaken, to sap energy from
ex: Leslie did not let sickness enervate her. She still managed to get out of bed and get into work.

def: overly sentimental to the point where it's disgusting
ex: Dwight found Kelly's tears mawkish to the point where he had to leave the room as not to stab her eyes out.

def: serving to warn, expressing reproach to correct
ex: Michael's admonitory speech to the office  noot to bother his newphew was not well received by the office, no matter how much Michael reproached them about it.

def: lacking imagination
ex: The Muggle Prime Minister's pedestrian outlook on what magic could do was laughable to Fudge. His lack of imagination on what wizards can do was not surprizing though.

def: suckup
ex: Andy might have started out as a sycophant, sucking up to Michael, but that quickly failed as Michael did not fall for it.

def: intended to attract notice and impress others; tawdry or vulgar
ex: Andy's ostentatious dresscode did not help his talk that he was a supporter of the common man when Dwight got rejected from the mall. His dresscode was rather showy. He even had cufflings on and a super expensive looking tie.

def: fearless
ex: Ron's intrepid charcater is sharply contrasted with Tommy'  who's afraid of his own shadow.

def: confusing or ambigious
ex: The office found Jim's position as co-manager equivocal for everyone especially as the two of them did not agree on everything.

def: bitterness and ill-will
ex: The acrimony over Angela between Dwight and Andy culminated in a duel between them in the office parking lot.

def: (n) aggressive boldness in social situations
ex: Ron and Harry both lacked the audacity to ask the girls they liked to the winter dance, and when they finally managed to find some bravery, they both got rejected.

def: extreme generosity and giving
ex: Michael's largess at 30 to give those high school kids their tuition did not go over well with kids 15 years later when he could not pay.

def: serving no useful purpose, more than is needed or desired
ex: The Department of Infinity Pools serves the superfluous job of building infinity pools in public parks and keeping them clean. This was the most useless part of the government of Pawnee, which was not needed or desired.

def: presenting favorable circumstances, likely to result or show signs of success
ex: Drinking the liquid made Harry's mission to get the memory from Slughorn much propitious. He felt that everything was conspiring to help him succeed at the mission Dumbledore gave him.

def: not wise
ex: It would be imprudent to leave your job before you have another job lined up.

def: to adopt or support an idea
ex: Leslie espoused the idea of building of a park over the pit. She supported it until she made it happen.

def: a subtle difference in opinion or attitude
ex: There are a lot of nuances in brewing a complicated potion like lady luck and as such many get it wrong.

def: reduce the length of something
ex: Dumbledore truncated his speech on staff appointments after the student uproar on Snape getting what he wanted.

def: characteristic of limited perspective, not fashionable or sophisticated
ex: Andy's Cornell talk was provincial to being a Cornell alum and did not go over well with the rest of the office.

def: harmful to living things
ex: Harry cooked up a potion in Slughorn's class that proved to be deletrious to any living thing. No living tissue could withstand it.

def: to suggest something subtly
ex: Andy intimated to Angela that he wanted sex but she flat out rejected his feeble attempt and subtle hint.

def: hinder or prevent
ex: Michael felt frustrated with everyone for their apathy about his boss's death

def: interpret in the wrong way
ex: Ron misconstrued Harry entering the triwizard competition as a desire for glory rather than the terrible plot Voldemort planned for. He got over that misunderstanding pretty quickly though.

def: requiring secret or mysterious knowledge
ex: Most of the stuff in the boook was arcane and did not much for modern day wizardry, yet evertheless found Hermonie's knokwledge of it to be of use every time.

def: very generous
ex:
Bob Vance's munificent donation to the office fundraising effortwas done for Phyllis. He paid $1000 wh
ich was very generous for a hug from Phyllis.

def: a strong liking
ex: Michael had a strong predilection towards Holy as soon as she entered the office. It was only with restraint from Jim that he did not ask her to marry him on the first day.

def: pronounce not gruilt of criminal charges
ex: Everyone was relieved the Scranton killer was not exonerated. Except for Toby, who still thought he was innocent and did not deserve criminal charges.

def: try to stir up public opinion
ex: Leslie tried to foment public support for a park in place of the pitch. She went canvassing around Pawnee knocking at houses asking for people's opinion and inviting them to a public hearing.

def: describe in detail
ex: Leslie handed April a binder that delineated her entire career over the next 10 years. It even included the exact month she would run for congress and win.

def: open to more than one interpretation
ex: It was pretty clear to everyone that Holy and Michael were meant for each other, but ambiguous to themselves.

def: make less severe or harsh
ex: Wallace tried to mitigate the damage done to Michael by losing Holy by sending him on a trip to Canada.

def: impossible to stop or event
ex: No matter how hard Leslie and Ron held on, change is inexorable and always came for their office and group. It could not be stopped.

def: practicing self-denial / unadorned in style or appearance / harsh in manner of temparment.
ex: The office's austere measures to lose weight were not effective in helping them lose weight. / Jim and Dwight presented an austere tree that lacked any hangings and expected the office to hang stuff on it. / The accounting department's austere relationship with the salesmen ended when the salesmen bought them donuts.

def: having or demonstrating the ability to recognize or draw fine distincitons
ex: Mark's incisive comments into how government works helped clear a few road blocks for Leslie from getting what she wanted.

def: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
ex: Ron's refractory attitude towards government was surprising considering he held a public office and got paid with government money. He's always resistent to getting anything governmental work done or respecting the role of the government he worked for.

def: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual
ex: Michael's most pronounced idiosyncrasy was putting on customes, like Prison Mike. This particular behavior of his is the most hilarious part of his character

def: (adj) marked by extreme care in treatment of details
ex: Daryll was very meticulous about how the storage was run, unlike Michael which ran the office haphazardly

def: lacking of emotion or enthusiasm
ex: Ben and Chris, who were used to general apathy towards government work in Indiana, were suprised by how much people cared in Pawnee and how many showed up to public meetings.

def: cunning or clever / exhbiting artistic skill
ex: Leslie's artful solution for Gryzzle to give them the land won her a lot of respect and solidified her lagacy.

def: exceedingly harmful, working or spreading in a hidden or injurious way
ex: Dumbledore found the ring's pernicious effect slowly destroying his hand and turning it black.

def: inducing mental lethargy, sleep inducing
ex: Stanely found all the meetings soporific. In fact, he's usually either napping in the meetings or playing crosswords.

def: an award or praise granted as a special honor
ex: Harry was not a fan of getting accolades for his defeat of the Dark Lord, yet he wrated as a hero in the wizarding community and was given a lot of awards he did not want.

def: to assert
ex: Tom always maintained that he was going to become a rich successful businessman, even when it looked really bleak for him.

def: so small they seem unimportant
ex: "I Braveheart" is an example of jokes that are negligible on the first watch, yet become more eminent as you watch the show a second and third time

def: (adj) being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold
ex: The tattoo shop owner's suggestion to build a disney park felt very impertinent to Leslie, especially since he was not invited, broke through a window to get in and it was a stupid unoriginal idea.
